alert.note: Alert for Cameron; Clinton; Elk; Lycoming; McKean; Potter; Tioga; Warren (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued March 28 at 11:53AM EDT until March 28 at 12:45PM EDT by NWS State College
info.description: The National Weather Service in State College PA has issued a * Snow Squall Warning for... Cameron County in north central Pennsylvania... Northwestern Clinton County in north central Pennsylvania... Elk County in north central Pennsylvania... Northern Lycoming County in north central Pennsylvania... Southern McKean County in north central Pennsylvania... Potter County in north central Pennsylvania... Southern Tioga County in north central Pennsylvania... Southern Warren County in north central Pennsylvania... * Until 1245 PM EDT. * At 1151 AM EDT, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from Wellsboro to Sheffield, moving southeast at 45 mph. HAZARD...Extremely poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts up to 30 mph. SOURCE...Radar indicated. IMPACT...Expect hazardous road conditions. This includes the following highways... Route 6 between Clarendon and west of Smethport...and from Port Allegany to the Bradford county line. Route 15 from south of Trout Run to Mansfield. Route 62 from south of Tidioute to south of Irvine. Route 219 from Brockport to near the Bradford Regional Airport. State Road 14 from Trout Run to the Bradford County line. State Road 59 from the Bradford Regional Airport to the Bradford Regional Airport. State Road 66 from Russell City to Kane. State Road 120 from Ridgway to Renovo. State Road 255 from north of Penfield to Johnsonburg. Locations impacted include... St. Marys, Ridgway, Kane, Mansfield, Wellsboro, Coudersport, Emporium, Renovo, Cameron, Wharton, Morris and Johnsonburg. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Consider avoiding or delaying travel until the snow squall passes your location. If you must travel, use extra caution and allow extra time. Rapid changes in visibility and slick road conditions may lead to accidents. There is no safe place on a highway when a snow squall hits. Visibility and traction are immediately lost in whiteout conditions, making it difficult or impossible to slow down and avoid stopped vehicles. Delay travel or safely exit the highway before the snow squall arrives. Wet roadways will quickly freeze. Black ice will cause roads, bridges and overpasses to become slick and dangerous. Slow down and be prepared for sudden loss of traction.
